> Another question: how would you handle a test that is supposed to pass bu=
t that
>  currently fails because of a problem you can't fix?  "All the tes=
ts must pass
> all the time" is fine if you have control over the entire co=
de, but what if one
> of the libraries you use has a bug?  While other are =
fixing the library, your
> tests are still broken but it's still ok to comm=
it new code (because no other
> new test fail)...

I always thought the sol=
ution was that you maintained a list of tests NOT 
to run. This list may va=
ry by platform (some tests don't work on platform X
because it doesn't supp=
ort threading, or whatever), and it may change over
time (as a bug in a lib=
rary is discovered, then later fixed). The list itself
is clear documentati=
on. The only trick is getting junit to not run the tests
on the list... dep=
ends on how you run your tests. (Eg: a master suite class
that collects tog=
ether all the tests, or an ant task that lists them...
whatever it is, enha=
nce it to respect your SKIPPED_TESTS list.)

-- Michael Chermside
